Package utils

Class AVL<T extends java.lang.Comparable<T>>

java.lang.Object
utils.AVL<T>
All Implemented Interfaces:
AVLInterface<T>
public class AVL<T extends java.lang.Comparable<T>>
extends java.lang.Object
implements AVLInterface<T>
A completely iterative AVL implementation (excluding certain order traversals).

  • Nested Class Summary

    Nested Classes

  • Method Details

    • add

      public void add​(T data)
      Description copied from interface: AVLInterface
      Add the data as a leaf in the BST. Should traverse the tree to find the appropriate location. You may assume null is never passed in. Should have a worst case running time of O(logn) If the data is already in the tree, do nothing.
      Specified by:
      add in interface AVLInterface<T extends java.lang.Comparable<T>>
      Parameters:
      data - the data to be added

    • rotateRight

      private void rotateRight​(AVLNode<T> target, AVLNode<T> parent, AVL.ChildType type)
      Rotates a given node to the right or clockwise and then sets the new root node as the child of a given parent.
      Parameters:
      target - the node to rotate.
      parent - the parent of target, the node to rotate.
      type - the child type of target in relation to parent.

    • rotateLeft

      private void rotateLeft​(AVLNode<T> target, AVLNode<T> parent, AVL.ChildType type)
      Rotates a given node to the left or counterclockwise and then sets the new root node as the child of a given parent.
      Parameters:
      target - the node to rotate.
      parent - the parent of target, the node to rotate.
      type - the child type of target in relation to parent.

    • remove

      public T remove​(T data)
      Description copied from interface: AVLInterface
      Removes the data from the tree. There are 3 cases to consider: 1: the data is a leaf. In this case, simply remove it 2: the data has one child. In this case, simply replace it with its child, then remove the child. 3: the data has 2 children. There are generally two approaches: replacing the data with either the next smallest element in the tree (commonly called the predecessor), or replacing it with the next largest element in the tree (commonly called the successor). For this assignment, use the successor. Should have a worst case running time of O(logn)
      Specified by:
      remove in interface AVLInterface<T extends java.lang.Comparable<T>>
      Returns:
      the data removed from the tree.

    • get

      public T get​(T data)
      Description copied from interface: AVLInterface
      Returns the data in the tree matching the parameter passed in (think carefully: should you use .equals or == ?). Should have a worst case running time of O(logn)
      Specified by:
      get in interface AVLInterface<T extends java.lang.Comparable<T>>
      Returns:
      the data in the tree equal to the parameter

    • height

      public int height()
      Description copied from interface: AVLInterface
      Calculate and return the height of the root of the tree. A node's height is defined as max(left.height, right.height) + 1. A leaf node has a height of 0. An empty tree should return -1. Should be calculated in O(1)
      Specified by:
      height in interface AVLInterface<T extends java.lang.Comparable<T>>
      Returns:
      the height of the root of the tree
